doc.title: blast

description.text: The Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) finds regions of local similarity between sequences.

doc.authors: Altschul, Madden, Schaeffer, Zhang, Miller, Lipman

description.text: Comparison between two sequences with Blast (NCBI)

interface.label:
Blast program (-p)?
Choose a program Blastp (protein/protein) Blastn (nucleotide/nucleotide) Blastx (translated nucleotide/ protein) tBlastn (protein/translated nucleotide) tBlastx (translated nucleotide/translated nucleotide)
- Blastp compares amino acid query sequences
- Blastn compares nucleotide query sequences
- tBlastx compares translated a nucleotide sequence and an amino acid sequence
- tBlastn compares an amino acid sequence translated and a nucleotide sequence
- tBlastx compares translated nucleotide sequences

Start of required region in first query sequence (-I)?
Location on query sequence
End of required region in first sequence (-I)
Start of required region in second sequence (-J)
End of required region in second sequence (-J)

xhtml:div.label:
Cost to open a gap (-G)?
Default: 5 for blastn; 10 for blastp, blastx and 11 for tblastn
Similarity matrix (-M) BLOSUM90 BLOSUM80 BLOSUM62 BLOSUM50 BLOSUM45 PAM30 PAM70 PAM250

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Mask off segments of the query sequence that have low compositional complexity, as determined by the SEG program of Wootton & Federhen (Computers and Chemistry, 1993) or, for BLASTN, by the DUST program of Tatusov and Lipman (in preparation). Filtering can eliminate statistically significant but biologically uninteresting reports from the blast output (e.g., hits against common acidic-, basic- or proline-rich regions), leaving the more biologically interesting regions of the query sequence available for specific matching against database sequences.

Filtering is only applied to the query sequence (or its translation products), not to database sequences. Default filtering is DUST for BLASTN, SEG for other programs. It is not unusual for nothing at all to be masked by SEG, when applied to sequences in SWISS-PROT, so filtering should not be expected to always yield an effect. Furthermore, in some cases, sequences are masked in their entirety, indicating that the statistical significance of any matches reported against the unfiltered query sequence should be suspect.

xhtml:div.label: Filter or Masking query sequence (DUST with blastn, SEG with others) (-F) Yes No

Filtering options (Filter must be true)?
Coiled-coiled filter ("C") Both SEG and coiled-coiled filters ("C;S") DUST filter for DNA ("D")
A coiled-coiled filter, based on the work of Lupas et al. (Science, vol 252, pp. 1162-4 (1991)) written by John Kuzio (Wilson et al., J Gen Virol, vol. 76, pp. 2923-32 (1995))

Masking options (Filter must be true)?
Masking with SEG should only be done during the building of initial words ("m S") Masking with coiled-coil should only be done during the building of initial words ("m D") Masking with DUST should only be done during the building of initial words ("m C") Lower-case masking (-U must be true) ("m")
A coiled-coiled filter, based on the work of Lupas et al. (Science, vol 252, pp. 1162-4 (1991)) written by John Kuzio (Wilson et al., J Gen Virol, vol. 76, pp. 2923-32 (1995)).
It is possible to specify that the masking should only be done during the process of building the initial words .
If the -U option (to mask any lower-case sequence in the input FASTA file) is used and one does not wish any other filtering, but does wish to mask when building the lookup tables then one should specify: -F 'm'

Use lower case filtering (-U)?
Yes No
This option specifies that any lower-case letters in the input FASTA file should be masked.

Expected value (-e)?
The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.

Word Size (-W)?
Use words of size N.
Zero invokes default behavior
Default values:
- 11 for blastn
- 3 for others

X dropoff value for gapped alignment (-X)?
This is the value that control the path graph region explored by Blast during a gapped extension (Xg in the NAR paper) (default for blastp is 15).
Default values:
- 30 for blastn
- 0 for tblastx
- 15 for others

Effective length of the search space (-Y)?
Use zero for the real size
Perform or not gapped alignment (not available with tblastx) (-g) Yes No

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: Query strand to search against second sequence (for blastx, tblastx or tblastn) (-S) Top (1) Bottom (2) Both (3)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: - Blastp compares amino acid query sequences
- tBlastx compares translated a nucleotide sequence and an amino acid sequence
- tBlastn compares an amino acid sequence translated and a nucleotide sequence
Default: 5 for blastn; 10 for blastp, blastx and 11 for tblastn
Default: 2 for blastn; 1 for blastp, blastx and tblastn
Limited values for gap existence and extension are supported for these programs.
A coiled-coiled filter, based on the work of Lupas et al. (Science, vol 252, pp. 1162-4 (1991)) written by John Kuzio (Wilson et al., J Gen Virol, vol. 76, pp. 2923-32 (1995))
A coiled-coiled filter, based on the work of Lupas et al. (Science, vol 252, pp. 1162-4 (1991)) written by John Kuzio (Wilson et al., J Gen Virol, vol. 76, pp. 2923-32 (1995)).
It is possible to specify that the masking should only be done during the process of building the initial words .

If the -U option (to mask any lower-case sequence in the input FASTA file) is used and one does not wish any other filtering, but does wish to mask when building the lookup tables then one should specify: -F 'm'
This option specifies that any lower-case letters in the input FASTA file should be masked.

The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.
This is the value that control the path graph region explored by Blast during a gapped extension (Xg in the NAR paper) (default for blastp is 15).
Use zero for the real size

comment.text: Mask off segments of the query sequence that have low compositional complexity, as determined by the SEG program of Wootton & Federhen (Computers and Chemistry, 1993) or, for BLASTN, by the DUST program of Tatusov and Lipman (in preparation). Filtering can eliminate statistically significant but biologically uninteresting reports from the blast output (e.g., hits against common acidic-, basic- or proline-rich regions), leaving the more biologically interesting regions of the query sequence available for specific matching against database sequences.

Filtering is only applied to the query sequence (or its translation products), not to database sequences. Default filtering is DUST for BLASTN, SEG for other programs. It is not unusual for nothing at all to be masked by SEG, when applied to sequences in SWISS-PROT, so filtering should not be expected to always yield an effect. Furthermore, in some cases, sequences are masked in their entirety, indicating that the statistical significance of any matches reported against the unfiltered query sequence should be suspect.

format.code: ("" , " -e "+str(value) )[value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.

interface.label:
Expected value (-e)?
The statistical significance threshold for reporting matches against database sequences; the default value is 10, such that 10 matches are expected to be found merely by chance, according to the stochastic model of Karlin and Altschul (1990). If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.

If the statistical significance ascribed to a match is greater than the EXPECT threshold, the match will not be reported. Lower EXPECT thresholds are more stringent, leading to fewer chance matches being reported. Fractional values are acceptable.
